notes: Both assess forward-looking adaptability/ontology/community claims as UNCERTAIN (shared: C72, C73, C75, C76, C82, C85). LLM also includes C68, C69, C70, C87.
Both support availability via DOI/web resource (C6).
Count of specifications (C74): LLM supports 49 in initial release; reviewers note a web listing of 38 and seek clarification.
Both support CLI subcommands/integration details for processing tools (shared: C52–C61). Sets are broader on each side but align on overlap.
Standardization/utility and immediate usefulness (C4, C71, C84): LLM is cautious due to lack of empirical evidence; reviewers are supportive.
Both support that seqspec index/integrations generate parameters for tools (shared: C62–C64).
Both support that seqspec can define options for preprocessing tools (C83).
Both support that lacking a formal spec limits utility/expandability (C29). LLM also discusses context (C26, C28).
Generalization/modularity across assays (C65): LLM deems unproven; reviewers accept it within the described functionality.
Both support CLI introduction/usage details (C49, C50).
Platform adaptability claim (C70): LLM is UNCERTAIN; reviewers are supportive.
Schema checking/readability (C51): LLM supports; reviewers question robustness of YAML validation, marking UNCERTAIN.
Visualization/comparison observations (C77–C81) appear only in LLM results; no corresponding peer evaluation found.
